Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic geometry is the study of solutions of polynomial equations, with many applications in other parts of mathematics, physics, and engineering. Some of the well-studied objects in algebraic geometry are the projective plane (the plane with additional "points at infinity") and curves on it. A natural question is that of finding the number of curves that satisfy certain special conditions, such as passing through fixed points or having special shapes, which was the starting point of a branch of algebraic geometry called enumerative geometry. During the past twenty years, the interaction between enumerative geometry and string theory in physics has resulted in many exciting new developments and has been a central area of current research. This research project aims to define and study new invariants, in a broader sense on general algebraic surfaces, that have connections to both mathematics and physics. These invariants contain sophisticated information about the number of singular curves, the geometric properties of the surface, and the parametrization space of singular curves. The project envisages development of a theoretical framework and tools for computation, as well as establishing connections between different subjects in mathematics. It will add to the understanding of geometry of algebraic varieties and has application to the description of spacetime in string theory.

This research project treats several problems in algebraic geometry, especially about the enumeration of singular curves on algebraic surfaces and its motivic generalization. Previous work has established that the numbers of varieties with certain given singularities satisfy universal formulas. This project concerns the generalization of these universal formulas in the motivic sense. The research defines a sequence of motivic invariants and studies their quantitative properties as well as their geometric interpretation. The work aims to extend the existing connections with Gromov-Witten theory, stable pairs theory, and modular forms for these new invariants, and to compare them with other motivic curve-counting invariants. One of the advantages of these new invariants is that they satisfy nice formulas and only depend on topological intersection numbers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the oldest problems in algebraic geometry is the number of singular curves on surfaces. This is not only a difficult problem in general and it has led to many theories in different branches of mathematics by generalization in various directions. During the past thirty years, such invariants have played a very important role in the interaction of physics and mathematics.

In this project we studied one special generalization of the numbers mentioned above, namely the universal polynomials of numbers of singular varieties satisfying given tangency conditions. The outcome is twofold.
Theoretically, we considered the most general case of singular objects satisfying tangency conditions with a smooth hypersurface on varieties of any dimension. We defined invariants to count them, and proved that those numbers are given by universal polynomials. Universality means the polynomials are independent of the choice of varieties and by plugging in certain invariants of the geometric data in the polynomials one can compute those numbers. We also described the shape of universal polynomials and their generating series. In order to develop such a theory  we constructed the cobordism theory of vector bundles and divisors on varieties and illustrated a beautiful map between the counting problem and the cobordism theory.

Computationally, we wrote programs to compute giga bytes of numbers of nodal curves on the projective plane and the product of two projective lines. This allowed us to compute around 780 terms of generating series and universal polynomials. The source code and computation results are available online for public use. Then we further found many unexpected properties and conjectures about the universal polynomials based on observations of the computational results. As applications we computed the number of nodal curves satisfying given tangency conditions on log K3 surface and corrected errors in previous papers. We also found an approach to combine those universal polynomials into much fewer ones. All of these work provided a clearer understanding and handy tools for computation for the invariants on any surface.
This proposal provides training grounds for an undergraduate student to complete her senior project.
